70.2c.58-1.98.9-4.04.9-6.2s-.32-4.22-.9-6.2l28.42-15.28C77.56 47.1 83.44 50 90 50c12.14 0 22-9.86 22-22S102.14 6 90 6s-22 9.86-22 22c0 1.98.28 3.9.78 5.72L40.14 49.1C36.12 44.76 30.38 42 24 42 11.86 42 2 51.86 2 64s9.86 22 22 22c6.38 0 12.12-2.76 16.14-7.12l28.64 15.38c-.5 1.84-.78 3.76-.78 5.74 0 12.14 9.86 22 22 22s22-9.86 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2023.09.057" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcis.2023.09.057</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0021979723017502&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="ab010"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">The stable three-dimensional framework and high operating voltage of sodium superionic conductor (NASICON)-type Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> has the potential to work with long cycle life and high-rate performance; however, it suffers from the poor intrinsic electronic conductivity and low <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a>. Herein, Ga</span><sup>3+</sup> is introduced into Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> to activate the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple at a high potential of 4.0&nbsp;V for enhancing energy density of the materials (Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>). After the partial substitution of Ga<sup>3+</sup> for V<sup>3+</sup>, three redox couples (V<sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>, V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> and V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup>) of V are reversibly converted in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, suggesting multi-electrons (&gt;2e<sup>−</sup>) involved in the reversible reaction, and simultaneously the electronic conductivity of the materials is effectively enhanced. As a result, the cathode with x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.75 exhibits excellent electrochemical properties: in the voltage range of 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V, delivering an initial capacity of 105 mAh/g at 1C with a capacity retention rate of 92.3% after 400 cycles, and providing a stable reversible capacity of 88.3 mAh/g at 40C; and in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, presenting the reversible capacity 152.3 mAh/g at 1C (497.6 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>), and cycling stably for 1000 cycles at 20C with a capacity decay of 0.02375% per cycle. It is found that the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes possess the sodium storage mechanism of single-phase and bi-phase reactions. This investigation presents a useful strategy to enhance the energy density and cycling life of NASICON-structured polyanionic phosphates by activating high-potential V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005">Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.25</sub>Ga<sub>0.75</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span><span> cathode exhibits high capacity, high <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> and long lifetime of </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about sodium ion battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion battery</a> due to Ga</span><sup>3+</sup> activation of V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> in the high potential region of Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>-based cathodes to achieve reversible multi-electron reversible reaction in a wide voltage range; and Ga<sup>3+</sup> is not involved in the electrochemical process, making the cycling process very stable.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (227KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (227KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979723017459"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S002197972301737X"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub></span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Multielectron reaction</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>High energy density</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>Ga<sup>3+</sup> doping</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010"><span>In the past 30&nbsp;years, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been successfully commercialized because of their high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> and long cycle life</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>. However, the scarcity and geographically unbalanced distribution of lithium resources has hindered the further development of LIBs<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a><span>. Therefore, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), which have similar working mechanisms with LIBs, has attracted wide attention due to the low cost and high natural abundance of <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> resource</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a><span>. However, the commercialization of SIBs is mainly restricted by the unsatisfactory capacity and low <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a><span> of <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a><span>. Thus, it is urgent to develop competitive cathodes with excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> so as to promote the practical applications of SIBs.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015"><span>Recently, various cathode candidates for the cathodes of SIBs have been developed, including layered <a href="/topics/materials-science/metal-oxide" title="Learn more about metal oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal oxides</a></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, Prussian blue homologues<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a> and polyanionic compounds<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>. It is worth noting that vanadium-based materials are widely used in various applications due to their unique properties<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a><span><span>, and they are also valuable for research in cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries. Among them, <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about superionic conductor from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">superionic conductor</a> (NASICON) type Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span><span>-based cathodes have been widely favored due to their stable three-dimensional framework for rapid <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion</a><span> diffusion, high operating voltage induced by the strong <a href="/topics/chemistry/inductive-effect" title="Learn more about inductive effect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inductive effect</a> of phosphates and tunable redox couples of V element. However, </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/purity" title="Learn more about pure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pure</a> Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) generally exhibits the capacity much smaller than the theoretical capacity of 117 mAh g<sup>−1</sup><span> in 2.0–4.5&nbsp;V, low energy density and poor cycling performance due to its limited redox couples, low operating voltage and poor <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a><span>. Therefore, various ions have been used to partially substitute V in the NVP to generate high-performance NVP-based <a href="/topics/chemistry/solid-solution" title="Learn more about solid solutions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid solutions</a>, such as Na</span></span><sub>3.05</sub>V<sub>1.03</sub>Fe<sub>0.97</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>3.2</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2.9</sub>(MoO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>0.1</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>3.9</sub>Mn<sub>0.95</sub>Zr<sub>0.05</sub>V(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.5</sub>Cr<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>@dual-carbon<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a><span>, etc. Nevertheless, most of NVP-based <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-solution" title="Learn more about solid solutions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid solutions</a> involve V</span><sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> redox couple with approximately 2 electrons involved within the voltage range of 2.0–4.5&nbsp;V, which limits the capacity and energy density of the materials. Very recently, it is found that the activation of high-potential V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup><span> in NVP-based materials makes full use of the four stable <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> states (V</span><sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup>) of the active central metal element V to achieve reversible conversion of the three redox couples and ultimately the reversible participation of multielectron (&gt;2e<sup>−</sup>) in the reaction, thus leading to the significant increase in the specific capacity and energy density. Single-metallic elements that may induce reversible multi-electron reactions can be learned from past reports<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. It has been found that reversible multi-electron reactions can be realized after doping NVP with Fe<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, Mn<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, Cr<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, or Al<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, respectively. For example, Chen et al. used Cr<sup>3+</sup> to activate the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> at high potential (4.0&nbsp;V) in non-aqueous electrolyte, resulting in a significant increase in operating voltage and specific capacity and thus exhibiting excellent specific capacity and long cycle life (Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.5</sub>Cr<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>: 163.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1C and 72.1% retention over 2650 cycles at 5C within 1.0–4.2&nbsp;V)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, while Sun et al. found that Al<sup>3+</sup> substitution for V<sup>3+</sup> in the NVP could reversibly activate the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple to achieve a multielectron reaction from V<sup>2+</sup> to V<sup>5+</sup>, giving excellent electrochemical properties (Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.5</sub>Al<sub>0.5</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>: 163 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1C and 87.9% retention over 500 cycles at 5C within 1.0–4.4&nbsp;V)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a><span>. Obviously, the substitution of unique <a href="/topics/chemistry/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a> for V</span><sup>3+</sup> in the NVP can effectively activate V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup><span> to achieve a multielectron <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> for developing high-performance NVP-based cathodes. It has been noted that Ga</span><sup>3+</sup><span><span> is frequently considered as a good <a href="/topics/materials-science/doping-additives" title="Learn more about dopant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dopant</a> to enhance the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> in LiNi</span><sub>0.8</sub>Co<sub>0.2</sub>O<sub>2</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, CoM<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a> etc. Interestingly, Ga and Al are in the same main group with similar physicochemical properties and thus may be reasonably expected that Ga<sup>3+</sup> can activate the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple in the NVP. Hu et al. combined the catalytic effects of VO<sub>x</sub> and Ga<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> to form in situ graphene-like graphitic layer decoration on Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.6</sub>Ga<sub>0.4</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, obtaining excellent rate performance (capacity 96.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 30C)<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>. Subsequently, Wang et al. reported that both Na<sub>3</sub>VGa(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>3</sub>VAl(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> achieve V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> conversion at 4.0&nbsp;V and investigated the reasons for the potential difference between V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> (4.0&nbsp;V) in NVP derivatives and theoretical V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> (4.6&nbsp;V) in NVP<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a><span>. To our knowledge, there are few reports on the multi-electron reaction in NASICON-type <a href="/topics/chemistry/polyanion" title="Learn more about polyanion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyanion</a> phosphates induced by the doping of Ga</span><sup>3+</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">Herein, non-electrochemically active Ga<sup>3+</sup> is used to activate high-potential V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple for achieving multi-electron effects over a wide voltage range in the NVP-based materials. After the addition of Ga<sup>3+</sup> (Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>), three redox couples of V<sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>, V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> and V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5</sup> for V are observed in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, and the electronic conductivity of the NVP-based cathodes is greatly improved. Consequently, the material with x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.75 exhibits excellent electrochemical performance: in 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, giving the capacity of 152.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 1C, corresponding to a high energy density of 497.6 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup> and presenting the capacity retention rate of 84.52% at 10C after 600 cycles, while in 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V, delivering the initial discharge capacity of 105 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 1C, with the capacity retention rate of 92.3% after 400 cycles, and providing 88.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> capacity at 40C.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials synthesis</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> were synthesized through a high-temperature solid-state reaction using NaH<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub> (≥99.0%, Sinopharm), NH<sub>4</sub>VO<sub>3</sub> (AR, 99%, Aladdin), Ga(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> xH<sub>2</sub>O (99.9%, Macklin) and C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>8</sub>O<sub>7</sub><span> (≥99.5%, Sinopharm) as raw materials. <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/citric-acid" title="Learn more about Citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Citric acid</a> (≥99.5%, Sinopharm) was utilized as a reducing agent, and the molar ratio of the citric acid and NH</span><sub>4</sub>VO<sub>3</sub> was 2:1. Initially, all the materials were mixed in 40&nbsp;mL anhydrous ethanol and ball-milled for 12&nbsp;h on a planetary ball mill. Then, the dried powder was annealed at 350&nbsp;°C for 4&nbsp;h and subsequently at 800&nbsp;°C for 8&nbsp;h in an Ar/H<sub>2</sub> (v/v, 95:5) atmosphere in a tube furnace to obtain Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> powders.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Materials characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">The crystal structure of the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> was measured by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Miniflex) with a Cu-Kɑ (λ&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.54 A) radiation source (2θ). The General Structural Analysis System (GSAS) software with EXPGUI interface was used for <a href="/topics/materials-science/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinement from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinement</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a><span><span><span>. The carbon in the cathode was characterized by <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Raman spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectroscopy</a> (HORIBA LabRAM HR 800). The chemical bonds and elemental valence states on the surface of the material were examined by an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy system (XPS, ESCALAB Xi). The microscopic morphology and structure of the prepared materials were observed by </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/field-emission-scanning-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about field emission scanning electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">field emission scanning electron microscopy</a><span> (SEM, zeiss/sigma500) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100F). The selected area </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a><span> (SAED) of the prepared materials was characterized by TEM. The element distribution can be detected by <a href="/topics/chemistry/energy-dispersive-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> mapping.</span></span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical performance</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span><span>The electrochemical tests of the materials were performed on CR2032 coin-type <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">batteries</a>. The </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode material</a> slurry was prepared by mixing Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span>, acetylene black and <a href="/topics/chemistry/polyvinylidene-fluoride" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene fluoride from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene fluoride</a> binder (PVDF) (AR, Guangzhou Kelud Co., LTD) in the mass ratio of 7:2:1 with an appropriate amount of </span><em>N</em><span><span>-methyl-pyrrolidone (NMP) (AR, Guangzhou Kelud Co., LTD) as the solvent. The slurry was uniformly applied to the <a href="/topics/chemistry/aluminum" title="Learn more about aluminum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum</a><span> foil and dried in a vacuum oven at 120&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h. And after that, it was cut into a 14&nbsp;mm diameter circular film. The separator was a <a href="/topics/chemistry/glass-fiber" title="Learn more about glass fiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glass fiber</a> (Whatman, GF/A), and 1&nbsp;M NaClO4 in ethylene carbonate/propylene carbonate (EC/PC, v/v 1:1) with 2&nbsp;wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) was used as the electrolyte. CR2032 button half batteries were assembled in a glove box containing high-purity argon gas. The charge/discharge curves, rate performance, long cycle stability and galvanostatic intermittent </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">titration</a> technique tests were performed using a battery automatic test system (LAND, CT2100A, Wuhan, China). The CV curves were tested using an electrochemical workstation (CHI760E, Shanghai, China). Electrochemical impedance (EIS) was measured over a frequency range of 0.01 to 10</span><sup>5</sup> Hz.</div></section><section id="s0030"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Computational details</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">The reaction kinetics can be further described by the following relationships<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" stretchy=&quot;false&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: transform="translate(345,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28" x="0" y="0"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-56"></use></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29" x="1159" y="0"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1894,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2950,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3925,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4633,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5634,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6609,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-7"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where i is the peak current of the CV curve, v is the scan rate, a and b are adjustable parameters and V is the fixed potential. The value of b determines the type of extraction/insertion of Na<sup>+</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span>The calculation of <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> (D</span><sub>Na</sub>) using GITT can be based on this equation<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>.<span class="display"><span id="e0020" class="formula"><span class="label">(6)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-8-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C0;</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C4;</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mfenced open=&quot;(&quot; close=&quot;)&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup><mspace width=&quot;3.33333pt&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mspace width=&quot;3.33333pt&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mfenced open=&quot;(&quot; close=&quot;)&quot; is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5265,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61" x="803" y="0"></use></g></g></g><g is="true"></g></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJSZ1-29" x="7928" y="-1"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><msup is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Δ</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Δ</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">τ</mi><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">&lt;</mo><mo is="true">&lt;</mo><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><msup is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow></msub><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace></mrow></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-8"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><msup is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">π</mi><mi is="true">τ</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Δ</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">s</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Δ</mi><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">τ</mi><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><mo is="true">&lt;</mo><mo is="true">&lt;</mo><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><msup is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi></mrow></msub><mspace width="3.33333pt" is="true"></mspace></mrow></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where L is the thickness of Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> on the aluminium foil, τ is the charging time per round and π is approximately equal to 3.1416.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about DFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT</a> calculations.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">All of the spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using the VASP program<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, which uses a plane-wave basis set and a projector augmented wave method (PAW) for the treatment of core electrons<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a><span>. The Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof exchange–correlation functional within a <a href="/topics/chemistry/generalized-gradient-approximation" title="Learn more about generalized gradient approximation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">generalized gradient approximation</a> (GGA-PBE)</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a> was used in our calculations. For the expansion of wavefunctions over the plane-wave basis set, a converged cutoff was set to 500&nbsp;eV. In geometry optimizations, all the structures were relaxed up to the residual atomic forces smaller than 0.02&nbsp;eV/Å, and the total energy was converged to 10<sup>−5</sup><span> eV. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/brillouin-zone" title="Learn more about Brillouin zone from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Brillouin zone</a> integration was performed on the (6&nbsp;×&nbsp;6&nbsp;×&nbsp;2) Monkhorst–Pack k-point mesh</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>. The DFT&nbsp;+&nbsp;U method was performed to correct the localized 3d electrons of V with a U of 3.1&nbsp;eV. The Bader charge analysis<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a><span> was applied to analyze the <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> states of V atom (V</span><sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup>) in Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.</div></section></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Result and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060">A series of NASICON-type Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.5, 0.75, 1) are prepared by an ordinary high-temperature solid-state reaction (abbreviated as NVP-Ga0, NVP-Ga0.5, NVP-Ga0.75 and NVP-Ga1, respectively). The <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting Information</span></span></a> section provides a comprehensive overview of all the experimental details. The crystal structures of the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S1</strong></span></span></a><span>. All samples possess high <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a><span> and can be associated with the typical <a href="/topics/chemistry/nasicons" title="Learn more about NASICON from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">NASICON</a><span> structure with a <a href="/topics/chemistry/rhombohedral-space-group" title="Learn more about rhombohedral space group from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">rhombohedral space group</a> of </span></span></span><em>R</em>-3<em>c</em><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) Rietveld refinements of the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0,0.5, 0.75 and 1) are carried out and the results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>a-b and</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S2</span></span></a><strong>a-2b.</strong> The fitting parameters of all the samples are within the acceptable values (R<sub>wp</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;10.61%/R<sub>p</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;7.72%/χ<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;=&nbsp;2.991 for the NVP-Ga0; R<sub>wp</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;7.98%/R<sub>p</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;6.33%/χ<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;=&nbsp;3.647 for the NVP-Ga0.5; R<sub>wp</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;7.27/R<sub>p</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;5.76%/χ<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;=&nbsp;2.966 for the NVP-Ga0.75; R<sub>wp</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;7.95%/R<sub>p</sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;6.65%/χ<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;=&nbsp;3.382 for the NVP-Ga1), showing a good matching between the calculated and experimental patterns. The average bond lengths of Na2-O related to electrochemical properties in the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> are calculated, and the results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S3</strong></span></span></a>. Among the four cathodes, the NVP-Ga0.75 possesses the longest Na2-O bond, implying the optimum electrochemical performance<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>c and S4</strong>, in the [MO<sub>6</sub>] (M&nbsp;=&nbsp;V, Ga) octahedral structure, the Ga atoms are located at the same positions as the V atoms. The [VO<sub>6</sub>]/[GaO<sub>6</sub><span>] <a href="/topics/chemistry/octahedral-crystal" title="Learn more about octahedra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">octahedra</a> are linked to [PO</span><sub>4</sub>] tetrahedra through oxygen atoms to form the basic units of [Ga<sub>0.75</sub>V<sub>1.25</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>], which creates ion channels for the rapid de/insertion of Na<sup>+</sup>, while the Na<sup>+</sup> ions occupy two distinct sites (6b, 18e), with Na1 situated in the six-fold coordination oxygen (NaO<sub>6</sub>) at 6b and Na2 situated in the eight-fold coordination oxygen (NaO<sub>8</sub>) at 18e<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. In general, the presence of Na1 contributes to the stability of the structural framework, whereas Na2 is more susceptible to being de/inserted during charging and discharging<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. It has been reported that reversible activation of V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> is possible only if the NVP-based cathode has sufficient Na<sup>+</sup> at the Na2 site<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. The crystal cell parameters of the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Tabs. S1-S2</strong></span></span></a>. Compared with the NVP-Ga0, the Na2 site of the NVP-Ga0.75 has sufficient Na<sup>+</sup>, which may be one of the reasons why the NVP-Ga0.75 can reversibly activate V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup><span>. The carbon contents of the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75, analyzed by CHNS <a href="/topics/chemistry/elemental-analysis" title="Learn more about elemental analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental analysis</a>, are 11.91&nbsp;wt% and 7.74&nbsp;wt%, respectively (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Tab. S3</strong></span></span></a><span>). The <a href="/topics/chemistry/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> </span><strong>in</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>d</strong> reveal two similar characteristic peaks of carbon for the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 at 1350 and 1580&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup>, respectively, representing disordered (D band) and graphitized (G band) carbons, separately; in addition, the I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span> values observed for the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 are almost similar (≈1.0), indicating partially graphitized carbon frames and thus suggesting a good <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a><span>. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ftir-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Fourier transform infrared spectroscopies from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fourier transform infrared spectroscopies</a> (FT-IR) of the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 show that the structural information of the two samples is almost identical, confirming the existences of PO</span><sub>4</sub> functional groups and V/Ga&nbsp;−&nbsp;O bonds<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>(<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>). The Survey X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) spectra <strong>(</strong><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S5-</span></span></a>6<strong>)</strong> of the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 show that Na, V, P, O and C elements are similar except that the NVP-Ga0.75 contains Ga<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>f</strong>, the C 1s spectra of both NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 show obvious three similar conductive carbon peaks, corresponding to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C (284.8&nbsp;eV), C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O (286.4&nbsp;eV) and O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O (288.6&nbsp;eV) bonds, respectively<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Figs. S7 and S8</strong></span></span></a> show that NVP-Ga0.75 and NVP-Ga0 have similar O 1s spectra, corresponding to P<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O (531.2&nbsp;eV), C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O (532.9&nbsp;eV) and absorbed H<sub>2</sub>O (535.4.6&nbsp;eV) bonds<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, respectively. The V 2p of NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>g</strong>, where two spin orbit peaks at 517.14/517.0&nbsp;eV and 524.0/523.7&nbsp;eV are attributed to V 2p<sub>3/2</sub> and V 2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively, suggesting the existence of the trivalent V<sup>3+</sup><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>; however, the peak of the NVP-Ga0.75 is slightly shifted toward the lower binding energy compared to the NVP-Ga0, suggesting that the electron density at the V-site increases after Ga<sup>3+</sup><span> doping and thus the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electron-transport" title="Learn more about electron transfer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transfer</a> rate increases</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><strong>h</strong>, the Ga 2p spectrum of the NVP-Ga0.75 shows that two signal peaks are located at 1145.6&nbsp;eV and 1118.6&nbsp;eV, respectively, corresponding to the trivalent Ga<sup>3+</sup> assigned to the orbitals of Ga 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and Ga 2p<sub>3/2</sub><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>. To make sure that the measured XPS results of the materials are credible, the XPS of the materials after etching 10&nbsp;nm is further tested. It is found that the XPS results before and after etching are very similar (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S9</strong></span></span></a>), indicating that it is feasible to use surface XPS to study the element valence states of Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr1.jpg" height="521" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (663KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (663KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/rietveld-refinement" title="Learn more about Rietveld refinements from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Rietveld refinements</a> for (a) NVP-Ga0 and (b) NVP-Ga0.75. (c) Crystal structures of NVP-Ga0.75. (d) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a><span> of NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75. (e) FT-IR spectra of NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75. Surface <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra of NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75: (f) C 1s, (g) V 2p and (h) Ga 2p.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065"><span>The micromorphology and <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a> of the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 are presented in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 2</span></span></a><span>, <a href="/topics/chemistry/point-group-s10" title="Learn more about S10 from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">S10</a> and S11</span>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>a and 2b</strong>, both samples possess the irregular micromorphology, but the NVP-Ga0.75 is slightly larger and more dispersed. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Figs. S10 and S11</strong></span></span></a>, the uniform elemental distributions are detected in the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>c and 2d,</strong><span> the cathode particles are effectively confined in a continuous and complete carbon matrix derived from <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a>, enhancing the overall conductivity of the NVP-Ga0.75</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>e</strong><span>, the NVP-Ga0.75 particles are uniformly coated with a carbon layer of&nbsp;∼&nbsp;3.5&nbsp;nm thickness, which can act as a binder to adhere the NVP-Ga0.75 <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> to the carbon matrix and the lattice stripe with a spacing of 0.43&nbsp;nm is detected in the material, corresponding to the (1</span>&nbsp;1&nbsp;<span>0) plane of the NASICON-type structure. Cleary, the NVP-Ga0.75 is <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/polycrystalline" title="Learn more about polycrystalline from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polycrystalline</a> and the elements of Na, Ga, V, P, O and C are uniformly distributed in the material (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><strong>f and 2&nbsp;g</strong>).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr2.jpg" height="420" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (775KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (775KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>Scanning <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about Electron Microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electron Microscope</a> (SEM) images of (a) NVP-Ga0 and (b) NVP-Ga0.75. (c-d) Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) images, (e) high-resolution TEM image (Experimental data were repeated twice with an error of less than 2%), (f) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about Selected Area Electron Diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Selected Area Electron Diffraction</a><span> (SAED) image and (g) <a href="/topics/chemistry/energy-dispersive-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy</a> (EDS) mapping image of NVP-Ga0.75.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">The electrochemical properties of the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> electrodes are examined in CR2032 coin-type cells. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a> presents the electrochemical properties of the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> electrodes in the range of 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V. <strong>From</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>a,</strong> the NVP-Ga0.75 exhibits excellent cycling stability with the capacity of 96.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and capacity retention of 92.3% after 400 cycles at 1C, much better than the other three electrodes (NVP-Ga0:18.9 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 20.6%; NVP-Ga0.5: 84.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 91.4%; and NVP-Ga1: 73.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 89.2%), showing the optimal electrochemical performance after the the moderate doping of Ga. The corresponding galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S12</strong></span></span></a>) show that the NVP-Ga0.75 has the weakest polarization, the NVP-Ga0.5 is the second weakest, and the NVP-Ga0 has the strongest polarization, suggesting that the reversibility of Ga-doped NVP is enhanced, and that the performance of NVP-0.75 is optimal. Among them, the NVP-0.75 has the best performance, followed by the NVP-Ga0.5. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>b and 3c</strong>, the GCD curves of the NVP-Ga0.75 at 1C within 400 cycles overlap much better than those of the NVP-Ga0, showing suppressed voltage decay and high-capacity retention. Moreover, the NVP-Ga0.75 shows an additional voltage plateau at 4.0&nbsp;V, indicating that the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> at high potential has been activated after the introduction of Ga into the NVP<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>d</strong> for the NVP-Ga0.75, the dQ/dV plot derived from the initial GCD curve of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>b</strong> highlights two pairs of sharp oxidation/reduction peaks, belonging to the redox pairs of V<sup>3+</sup>/<sup>4+</sup> and V<sup>4+</sup>/<sup>5+</sup>, respectively, corresponding to two voltage plateaus of the GCD curves at&nbsp;∼&nbsp;3.4&nbsp;V and&nbsp;∼&nbsp;4.0&nbsp;V, respectively, which indicates a continuous transformation of V<sup>3+</sup> to V<sup>4+</sup> and then to V<sup>5+</sup>. On the other hand, the dQ/dV plot of the NVP-Ga0 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S13</strong></span></span></a>) only exhibits one pair of oxidation/reduction peak, in agreement with the redox couples of V<sup>3+</sup>/<sup>4+</sup>. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the NVP-Ga0.75 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>) at 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> in the range of 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V shows two pairs of distinct redox peaks, corresponding to V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> and V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup>, respectively, further indicating that high-potential V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> is involved in the electrochemical process. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>f</strong>, the NVP-Ga0.75 exhibits a reversible capacity of 109.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.5C, and gives a stable capacity of 88.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 40C, while the rate is reset to 0.5C, the capacity is returned to 106.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, showing much superior rate performance than the material with x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>g</strong>, the NVP-Ga0.75 has a high reversible capacity of 95.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> with a capacity retention rate of 91.35% after 500 cycles at 10C.
