Even at an oversized rate of 20C, the NVP-Ga0.75 still works stably and has a capacity of up to 79.5 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 500 cycles, maintaining 78.63% of the initial capacity (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><strong>h</strong>).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr3.jpg" height="378" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (545KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (545KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about Electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical properties</a> within 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V: (a) Cycling performances of Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> at 1C. The selected GCD curves of (b) NVP-Ga0.75 and (c) NVP-Ga0 at 1C. (d) dQ/ dV curves at 1C and (e) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of NVP-Ga0.75 and NVP-Ga0. (f) Rate performances, Cycling performances at (g) 10C and (h) 20C of NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">The electrochemical behaviors of the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> electrodes are investigated in the range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V to highlight the superiority of multielectron <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> induced by the doping of Ga</span><sup>3+</sup> in the NVP and the results are show in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>.</strong> From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>a</strong>, the NVP-Ga0.75 presents a reversible capacity of 152.3 mAh/g (497.6 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>) with the capacity retention of 90% after 70 cycles at 1C, much better than the other three electrodes (NVP-Ga0: 160 mAh/g and 67%; NVP-Ga0.5: 145 mAh/g and 81%; and NVP-Ga1: 114.4 mAh/g and 89%). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>b and S14</strong> show the charge/discharge curves of the NVP-Ga0.75 and NVP-Ga0 in the first ten cycles at 1C, respectively. Compared with those of the NVP-Ga0, the curves of the NVP-Ga0.75 exhibits much smaller polarization and much better overlap<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. Obviously, the NVP-Ga0.75 presents an additional voltage plateau at 4.0&nbsp;V, corresponding to the conversion of V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> at high operating potential, which accounts for the energy density advantage of the NVP-Ga0.75. The cycling stabilities of the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 are evaluated and the results show in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>c-d and S15</strong>. The NVP-Ga0.75 has a capacity of 117.7 mAh/g after 210 cycles at 5C, with a capacity retention rate of 93.01%, much higher than the undoped cathode (38.9 mAh/g and 35.44%; <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>). As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>d</strong><span>, the NVP-Ga0.75 has an initial discharge capacity of 91 mAh/g at 10C and exhibits the impressive reversible capacity retention of 84.52% after 600 cycles, far better than the material with x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0 (94.3 mAh/g and 10.81% after 600 cycles). Even at 20C, the NVP-Ga0.75 still exhibits the capacity of 70 mAh/g with the capacity retention of 76.25% after 1000 cycles, a capacity decay of 0.02375% per cycle and average Coulomb efficiency of 99.96% within 1000 cycles. In order to further prove the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> of the NVP-Ga0.75, the XRD patterns of the material cycled for different cycles are analyzed and the results are shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>. Clearly, there is almost no change in the XRD patterns of the material before and after cycling, suggesting excellent structure stability. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>f</strong> shows the electrochemical impedance spectroscope (EIS) of the NVP-Ga0.75 cycled for different cycles at 10C. It can be observed that the shapes of the recorded EIS are quite similar after cycling for different cycles. With the increase of the number of cycles, the charge transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) decreases slightly (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>g</strong>), indicating that the electrode has ultrafast reaction kinetics, and thus exhibits excellent rate performance and long cycle stability. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>i</strong>, the NVP-Ga0.75 provides a reversible capacity of 149.5 mAh/g at 0.5C and shows a stable capacity of 58.9 mAh/g at 40C, while when the rate returns to 0.5C, the capacity can return to 142.3 mAh/g, which is significantly better than the other three cathode. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><strong>h and</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Tab. S4</strong></span></span></a><strong>,</strong> the NVP-Ga0.75 exhibits excellent specific capacity and cycling performance in the voltage ranges of both 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V and 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V, being comparable/superior to most of the recently reported similar materials<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr4.jpg" height="567" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (693KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (693KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about Electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical properties</a> within 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V: (a) Cycling performances of Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span><span> at 1C and (b) Charge/discharge curves of the NVP-Ga0.75 in the initial ten cycles. Cycling performances of NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 at (c) 5C and (d) 10C. (e) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a>, (f) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/spectrometer" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> spectra and (g) the variation of R</span><sub>ct</sub> after different cycles at 10C. (h) Ragone plots of the state-of-the-art materials. (i) Rate performances of Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080"><em>Ex-situ</em> XRD and <em>ex-situ</em><span><span> XPS are used to investigate the <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage mechanism of the NVP-Ga0.75 cathode during </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> in the range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>a and 5b</strong><span>, the diffraction peaks of the cathode shift, disappear/appear or split during <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a>. Specifically, during the charging to 3.3&nbsp;V, the diffraction peaks of the NVP-Ga0.75 continuously shift to higher angles, indicating the removal of Na</span><sup>+</sup> ions and lattice shrinkage. At this stage, there is a typical single-phase reaction mechanism that lacks the appearance of a new phase and the disappearance of the original phase, and exhibits the V<sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup> conversion. When the voltage further increases to 3.8&nbsp;V, the crystal faces of (0&nbsp;2&nbsp;4) and (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;6) move towards a higher angle than those of the previous phase, in which V<sup>3+</sup> is oxidized to V<sup>4+</sup>, both (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;4) and (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;3) peaks split into two peaks, and the (3&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) peak disappears, suggesting a typical bi-phase reaction<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>. This process consumes 1.25Na<sup>+</sup> at Na2 sites and the remaining 0.75Na<sup>+</sup> at Na2 sites may be responsible for the reversible conversion of V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup>. When charging to 4.0&nbsp;V, the diffraction peaks are shifted towards higher angles, and V<sup>4+</sup> is converted to V<sup>5+</sup>. In contrast to the charging process, when the discharge is completed (1.4&nbsp;V), the diffraction peaks are completely reversed to the initial peaks’ positions, indicating a reversible de/intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> ions during charging and discharging process. The CV curves in the first three cycles for the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 at 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> within 1.4&nbsp;∼&nbsp;4.2&nbsp;V are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>. The separations of anode and cathode peaks (ΔV) for the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Tab. S5</strong></span></span></a>. The ΔV values of the NVP-Ga0.75 are much smaller and the coincidence of the curves of the NVP-Ga0.75 are much better that those of the material with x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, indicating that the introduction of Ga<sup>3+</sup> into the NVP greatly improves the reversibility of the electrochemical reaction<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>. Two pairs of peaks of the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 at about 1.7&nbsp;V and 3.5&nbsp;V are attributed to the common redox pairs of V<sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup> and V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> in NVP-based electrodes, respectively. In addition, the NVP-Ga0.75 present an additional redox couple at 4.0&nbsp;V (V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup>) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>). The ex-situ XPS spectra of the NVP-Ga0.75 under different charge/discharge states (pristine, charged (3.6&nbsp;V), charged (4.2&nbsp;V) and discharged (1.4&nbsp;V) are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>d and 5e</strong>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>d</strong>, the V element exists in a trivalent form (V<sup>3+</sup>) in the initial sample. When charged to 3.6&nbsp;V, the peaks move towards higher binding energies, at which V element is present only as V<sup>4+</sup>, indicating a complete transformation of V<sup>3+</sup> to V<sup>4+</sup>. When continually charging to 4.0&nbsp;V, V<sup>4+</sup> and V<sup>5+</sup><span> coexist in the NVP-Ga0.75, indicating <a href="/topics/chemistry/partial-oxidation" title="Learn more about partial oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">partial oxidation</a> of V</span><sup>4+</sup> to V<sup>5+</sup>, while when discharging to 1.4&nbsp;V, the V element is reduced to V<sup>2+</sup>. In contrast, the peaks of Ga 2p <strong>(</strong><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><strong>e)</strong> are consistently similar to the initial state, indicating that it only exists as trivalent Ga<sup>3+</sup> without own electrochemical reaction process. These prove that V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple has electrochemical reactivity and can reversibly participate in the electrochemical process involved multiple electrons in the NVP-Ga0.75. To further investigate the mechanism of Ga<sup>3+</sup> induced reversible V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> in NVP-Ga0.75, the change of ion occupancy during charging and discharging is calculated. The XRD Rietveld refinements of pristine and the material charged to 4.2&nbsp;V are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S16</strong></span></span></a>. From <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Figs. S16</strong></span></span></a><strong>a-16b</strong> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Table S6-</strong></span></span></a><strong>7</strong>, it can be seen that compared to the pristine, Na2 occupancy is close to 0 when charging to 4.2&nbsp;V, while Na1 occupancy remains almost constant, and the crystal structures at pristine and 4.1&nbsp;V (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Figs. S16</strong></span></span></a><strong>c-16d</strong>) specifically show that after charging only the Na<sup>+</sup> at the Na2 site is extracted, suggesting that the reversible activation of V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> is due to sufficient Na<sup>+</sup> occupying the Na2 site, which is also consistent with the study that Na<sub>3.4</sub>V<sub>1.6</sub>Fe<sub>0.4</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> can reversibly activate V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr5.jpg" height="360" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (459KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (459KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a) 2D contour plots of <em>ex-situ</em><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a><span><span> and (b) corresponding <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a> of NVP-Ga0.75 at different charging and discharging states. (c) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 for the first three cycles using 1&nbsp;M NaClO4 in ethylene carbonate/propylene carbonate (EC/PC, v/v 1:1) with 2&nbsp;wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as the electrolyte. </span></span><em>Ex-situ</em><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectra of (d) V 2p (e) Ga 2p of NVP-Ga0.75.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085">To further elucidate the reasons for the improved electrochemical properties after the doping of Ga<sup>3+</sup><span>, the <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemical-kinetics-characteristics" title="Learn more about kinetic properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">kinetic properties</a> of the NVP-Ga0.75 are investigated and the results are shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>. The Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> (D</span><sub>Na</sub>) of the NVP-Ga0 and NVP-Ga0.75 are evaluated by galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>a and b</strong>). Apparently, the calculated D<sub>Na</sub> values of 10<sup>−7</sup>&nbsp;∼&nbsp;10<sup>−10</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>−1</sup> for the NVP-Ga0.75 are higher than those of the NVP-Ga0 (10<sup>−8</sup>&nbsp;∼&nbsp;10<sup>−12</sup> cm<sup>2</sup> s<sup>−1</sup>), which are also higher that most of the reported Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>-based cathode materials<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, being favorable for the rate performance. The EIS reveals that the NVP-Ga0.75 has much lower R<sub>ct</sub> than NVP-Ga0 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><strong>Fig. S17</strong></span></span></a>), implying that the NVP-Ga0.75 has much superior reaction kinetics than the material without the Ga doping. The CV curves of the NVP-Ga0.75 at different scan rates are used to understand the contribution of capacitance to the total capacity (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>c</strong>). As the scan rate increases, the oxidation/reduction peaks move to higher and lower potentials, respectively. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>d</strong>, the b values of peaks 1&nbsp;∼&nbsp;6 range from 0.54 to 0.96, indicating the coexistence of capacitive and diffusive behaviors in the NVP-Ga0.75. Generally, there are two types of processes for Na<sup>+</sup><span> storage in SIBs: a Faradic process that ensures the operating voltage with a transition metal <a href="/topics/chemistry/redox-reactions" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a>, and a non-Faradic process that contributes to the rate and cycling performance (referred to as pseudocapacitive process)</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. The pseudocapacitive contribution of the NVP-Ga0.75 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><strong>e</strong>) is 65% at 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> and increases with increasing scan rate, finally reaching 81% at 0.5&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, showing that the electrochemical behavior of the material is mainly influenced by pseudocapacitance. Therefore, the extended lifetime and improved rate performance of the NVP-Ga0.75 may be mainly attributed to non-Faradic processes<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr6.jpg" height="327" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (387KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (387KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <span>Kinetics performances: <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about GITT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GITT</a> curves and D</span><sub>Na</sub> of (a) NVP-Ga0.75 and (b) NVP-Ga0. (c) CV curves of NVP-Ga0.75 at various scan rates. (d) Corresponding b-values and (e) pseudo-capacitance contributions.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090">The calculated net charges of V atoms are computed using Bader charge analysis, which are shown in the <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>. To quantitatively analyze the redox mechanism of Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Ga-doped Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>), during desodiation processes, the Bader charges of V are calculated as a function of Na content&nbsp;<em>×</em>&nbsp;(<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>), using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. During the Na<sup>+</sup> extraction process of Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (4 ⩾ <em>x</em><span> ⩾ 1), the Bader charge of V increases, i.e.&nbsp;+&nbsp;1.48e → +1.85e → +2.05e, which imply the <a href="/topics/chemistry/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox processes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox processes</a> of V</span><sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> for Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> during desodiation. When calculating, Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.25</sub>Ga<sub>0.75</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> is approximated to Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>. For Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, the Bader charge of V increases in the following order: +1.46e → +1.85e → +2.04e → +2.13e as Na content decreases (4 ⩾ <em>x</em> ⩾ 1.33), indicating the redox processes of V<sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> for Na<sub>x</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> during desodiation. These <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/density-functional-theory" title="Learn more about DFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT</a> results show that the introduction of Ga</span><sup>3+</sup> into Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> can activate the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple, which are in good agreement with experimental results.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr7.jpg" height="421" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (753KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (753KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0021979723017502-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. The optimized geometry structures of (a) Na<sub>4</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, (b) Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, (c) Na<sub>1</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, (d) Na<sub>4</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, (e) Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, (f) Na<sub>1.83</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, and (g) Na<sub>1.33</sub>V<sub>1.17</sub>Ga<sub>0.83</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">In summary, by activating the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox pair at a high potential of 4.0&nbsp;V to increase the energy density of the material, we developed a Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2-x</sub>Ga<sub>x</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode for sodium-ion batteries with a high energy density that outperforms similar materials that have been reported<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>. It is found that the partial substitution of Ga<sup>3+</sup> for V<sup>3+</sup> induces three redox couples of V<sup>2+</sup>/V<sup>3+</sup>, V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> and V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, and simultaneously lengthens the average bond length of Na2-O closely related to electrochemical properties and increases the electron density at the V-site. Therefore, the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.25</sub>Ga<sub>0.75</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode exhibits excellent electrochemical properties: in the voltage range of 2.2–4.2&nbsp;V, giving an initial capacity of 105 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> with a capacity retention rate of 92.3% at 1C after 400 cycles, and providing a stable reversible capacity of 88.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 40C, while in the voltage range of 1.4–4.2&nbsp;V, presenting the reversible capacity of 152.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 1C (497.6 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>) that means that the multielectron effect is realized and cycling stably for 1000 cycles at 20C with a capacity decay of 0.02375% per cycle. The present work verifies the reversible activation of V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> in NVP after Ga<sup>3+</sup> doping, and provides a feasible approach to develop high-energy–density NASICON-structured polyanionic phosphates as advanced cathodes for sodium ion batteries by activating high-potential V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>.</div></section><section id="s0050"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105"><strong>Yuxiang Chen:</strong> Investigation, Methodology, Conceptualization, Writing – original draft, Software. <strong>Xiangyue Liao:</strong> Software, Visualization, Formal analysis. <strong>Peng Wang:</strong> Data curation, Visualization. <strong>Ji Chen:</strong> Software. <strong>Xiaoqin Zhang:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Xingqiao Wu:</strong> Software, Visualization. <strong>Sean C. Smith:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Dunmin Lin:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision. <strong>Xin Tan:</strong> Data curation, Software, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Qiaoji Zheng:</strong> Resources, Writing – review &amp; editing.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">This work was supported by <span id="gp015">Natural Science Foundation of Sichuan Province</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022NSFSC0222</span></span></a>) and Sichuan Science and Technology Program (2023NSFSC0439). The authors also appreciate the Shiyanjia Lab (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="http://www.shiyanjia.com" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">www.shiyanjia.com</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a>) for the XPS tests and eceshi (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="http://www.eceshi.cn" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">www.eceshi.cn</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a>) for the TEM tests.</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0060"><h2 id="st090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Li, J. Li, R. Li, X. Li, J. Gao, S.M. Hao, W. Zhou</div><div id="ref-id-h0030" class="title text-m">Study on sodium storage properties of manganese-doped sodium vanadium phosphate cathode materials</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Battery Energy, 2 (2) (2023), p. 20220042</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" Ed., 62 (14) (2023), p. e202219304</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85148635576&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=A%20high-energy%20nasicon-type%20Na3.2MnTi0.8V0.23%20cathode%20material%20with%20reversible%203.2-electron%20redox%20reaction%20for%20sodium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2023&amp;author=P.%20Hu&amp;author=T.%20Zhu&amp;author=C.%20Cai&amp;author=X.%20Wang&amp;author=L.%20Zhang&amp;author=L.%20Mai&amp;author=L.%20Zhou" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0280" id="ref-id-b0280" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0280"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">P. Guo</div><div id="ref-id-h0280" class="title text-m">Optimizing vanadium redox reaction in Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathodes for sodium-ion batteries by the synergistic effect of additional electrons from heteroatoms</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">ACS Appl. Wu</div><div id="ref-id-h0285" class="title text-m">An advanced high-entropy fluorophosphate cathode for sodium-ion batteries with increased working voltage and energy density</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Adv. Mater., 34 (14) (2022), p. 2110108</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85125226430&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=An%20advanced%20high-entropy%20fluorophosphate%20cathode%20for%20sodium-ion%20batteries%20with%20increased%20working%20voltage%20and%20energy%20density&amp;publication_year=2022&amp;author=Z.Y.%20Gu&amp;author=J.Z.%20Guo&amp;author=J.M.%20Cao&amp;author=X.T.%20Wang&amp;author=X.X.%20Zhao&amp;author=X.Y.%20Zheng&amp;author=W.H.%20Li&amp;author=Z.H.%20Sun&amp;author=H.J.%20Liang&amp;author=X.L.%20Wu" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0290" id="ref-id-b0290" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0290"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">Y. Liu, C. Sun, Q. Ni, Z. Sun, M. Li, S. Ma, H. Jin, Y. Zhao</div><div id="ref-id-h0290" class="title text-m">Enhanced electrochemical performance of nasicon-type sodium ion cathode based on charge balance theory</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Energy Storage Mater., 53 (2022), pp. 881-889</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><a class="anchor pdf link anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829722005281" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View article</span></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85139738117&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Enhanced%20electrochemical%20performance%20of%20nasicon-type%20sodium%20ion%20cathode%20based%20on%20charge%20balance%20theory&amp;publication_year=2022&amp;author=Y.%20Liu&amp;author=C.%20Sun&amp;author=Q.%20Ni&amp;author=Z.%20Sun&amp;author=M.%20Li&amp;author=S.%20Ma&amp;author=H.%20Jin&amp;author=Y.%20Zhao" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (23)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2095495624004029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A high-entropy-designed cathode with V&lt;sup&gt;5+&lt;/sup&gt;-V&lt;sup&gt;2+&lt;/sup&gt; multi-redox for high energy density sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Chemistry</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">What is more, HE-N3VM3P3 has the fantastic capacity retention of 97.6% after 1000 cycles, far better than the others (79.9%, 95.8%, and 93.3%) (Fig. 3d). From Fig. 3(e and f), HE-N3VM3P3 can also deliver more superior rate capabilities (107 mA h g−1@30 C, 97 mA h g−1@50 C, and 76 mA h g−1@90 C) compared to the bare NVP, HE-N3VM2P3, and HE-N3VM4P3 materials, which still shows unprecedented progressiveness compared with previous studies [18,22,31,32,47,49,51,52] (Fig. 3g). To test their high-current charging-discharging capability, the long-periodic cycling at 30 C is obtained (Fig. 3h).</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) is gifted with fast Na<sup>+</sup> conductive NASICON structure. But it still suffers from low electronic conductivity and inadequate energy density. Herein, a high-entropy modification strategy is realized by doping V<sup>3+</sup> site with Ga<sup>3+</sup>/Cr<sup>3+</sup>/Al<sup>3+</sup>/Fe<sup>3+</sup>/In<sup>3+</sup> simultaneously (i.e. Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2−</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>(GaCrAlFeIn)<em><sub>x</sub></em>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>; <em>x</em> &nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.04, 0.06, and 0.08) to stimulate the V<sup>5+</sup>⇋V<sup>2+</sup> reversible multi-electron redox. Such configuration high-entropy can effectively suppress the structural collapse, enhance the redox reversibility in high working voltage (4.0&nbsp;V), and optimize the electronic induced effect. The in-situ X-ray powder diffraction and in-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy tests efficaciously confirm the robust structural recovery and far lower polarization throughout an entire charge-discharge cycle during 1.6–4.3&nbsp;V, respectively. Moreover, the density functional theory calculations clarify the stronger metallicity of high-entropy electrode than the bare that is derived from the more mobile free electrons surrounding the vicinity of Fermi level. By grace of high-entropy design and multi-electron transfer reactions, the optimal Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>1.7</sub>(GaCrAlFeIn)<sub>0.06</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> can exhibit perfect cycling/rate performances (90.97%@5000 cycles@30 C; 112&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>@10 C and 109&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>@30 C, 2.0–4.3&nbsp;V). Furthermore, it can supply ultra-high 185&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> capacity with fantastic energy density (522&nbsp;W&nbsp;h&nbsp;kg<sup>−1</sup>) in half-cells (1.4–4.3&nbsp;V), and competitive capacity (121&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>) as well as energy density (402&nbsp;W&nbsp;h&nbsp;kg<sup>−1</sup>) in full-cells (1.6–4.1&nbsp;V), demonstrating enormous application potential for sodium-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S138589472404960X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Advancements in cathode technology, recycling strategies, and market dynamics: A comprehensive review of sodium ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Chemical Engineering Journal</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Ga is added to Na3V2(PO4)3 to activate the V4+/V5+ redox couple, enhancing energy density. The resulting Na3V1.25Ga0.75(PO4)3 cathodes exhibit excellent electrochemical performance and stability, offering a promising strategy for improving NASICON-structured polyanionic phosphates [116]. At the same, a NASICON-type Na4MnV(PO4)3/C compound is used as a high-performance cathode material for SIBs [117].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010">The rising demand for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) in commercial applications emphasizes the importance of meeting commercial criteria. Despite their potential, SIBs encounter challenges related to specific energy, cycling life, and specific power due to the unique characteristics of sodium ions. Design strategies, surface engineering, and structural modifications for cathode materials have been devised to improve the electrochemical performance of SIBs. In SIBs, the energy density primarily depends on the choice of cathode materials. Common cathode materials nowadays include transition metal oxides, polyanionic compounds, and Prussian blue analogs (PBAs). Enhancing these materials through targeted modifications to overcome their limitations is crucial for transitioning them from lab-scale to practical use. However, there are still some challenges to address before cathode materials can be effectively utilized for large-scale energy storage in SIBs.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Recycling spent SIBs poses significant economic and environmental challenges, particularly compared to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). Despite progress in cathode materials, thorough environmental assessments and detailed inventory data are lacking for SIBs. The early stage of their development restricts metal recycling in SIBs, underscoring the significance of end-of-life treatment. Pyrometallurgy and hydrometallurgy are commonly employed for metal recovery, with pyrometallurgy favored for SIBs due to reduced sodium evaporation risks.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">The marketing and commercialization trends in SIBs reflect the growing demand for renewable energy solutions. SIBs, with their potential for grid-scale energy storage, are expected to support the expansion of renewable energy infrastructure. However, overcoming technological challenges and reducing costs are key to SIB commercialization. In this regard, startups are playing a significant role in advancing SIB technologies for large-scale energy storage applications. The collaboration between companies and advancements in manufacturing facilities are driving SIB production, marking substantial progress towards commercialization. This paper aims to provide a comprehensive review of the current research and advancements in SIB technology.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2041652024007405"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Emerging high voltage V&lt;sup&gt;4+&lt;/sup&gt;/V&lt;sup&gt;5+&lt;/sup&gt; redox reactions in Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;-based cathodes for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Chemical Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom">Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) cathode materials with the advantages of long cycle life and superior thermal stability have been considered promising cathode candidates for SIBs. However, the unsatisfactory energy density derived from low theoretical capacity and operating voltage (3.35 V <em>vs.</em> Na<sup>+</sup>/Na, based on the V<sup>3+</sup>/V<sup>4+</sup> redox couple) inevitably limits their practical application. Therefore, the activation of the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple (∼4.0 V <em>vs.</em> Na<sup>+</sup>/Na) in NVP-based cathode materials to boost the energy density of SIBs has attracted extensive attention. Herein, we first analyze the challenges of activation of the V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox couple in NVP-based cathode materials. Subsequently, the recent achievement of NVP-based cathode materials with activated V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox reactions for SIBs is overviewed. Finally, further research directions of high voltage V<sup>4+</sup>/V<sup>5+</sup> redox reactions in NVP-based cathodes are proposed. This review provides valuable guidance for developing high energy density NVP-based cathode materials for SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1007/s40820-024-01526-x" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Optimization Strategies of Na&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; Cathode Materials for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
